conclusion: The two rods and the rails form one closed circuit because the rails are perfect conductors (resistance ≈ 0) and each rod has resistance R=0.1Ω.

premise: The two rods and the rails form one closed circuit.
The rods are moving on the same pair of rails in the same uniform field B.
conclusion: The motional emfs are Ea=BLva, Eb=BLvb.

premise: The motional emfs are Ea=BLva, Eb=BLvb.
conclusion: The net emf that drives the circuit is the difference of the two, so the instantaneous current is I=(Ea−Eb)/Rtot=BL(va−vb)/0.2.

conclusion: On rod a the force is opposite to va: FBa=−k′(va−vb).

premise: Each rod experiences a magnetic force FB=IBL=B²L²/0.2(va−vb)≡k′(va−vb), k′=B²L²/0.2=0.05 N·s m−1.
conclusion: On rod b it is equal and opposite: FBb=+k′(va−vb).
The two magnetic forces are an internal action–reaction pair.

premise: The pulling force on a is +F=+2N and gravity components on a and b are −(ma+mb)gsinθ=−2 N.
conclusion: The net external force on the system is zero at every instant: F−(ma+mb)gsinθ=2N−2N=0.
The total external impulse is zero, so the momentum along the rail is conserved.
